Award.AwardTitle: Mantle Signals in Arcs: Transport Models From Geochemistry and Seismicity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed study will explore magma transport rates in the middle to lower crust of convergent margin volcanoes and therefore address one of the most fundamental questions in geodynamics: How do magmas move from their source region in the mantle wedge to the surface? Furthermore, results from this study will provide first-order controls on arc magma petrogenesis, connecting the mantle source and melting process with the crustal plumbing system as well as provide insights on the aggregation of mantle-derived melts beneath arc volcanoes. The project is designed to use an integrative approach combining constraints from geochemistry, seismology, and fluid dynamics. The project will lead to a better understanding of magma transport beneath active volcanoes and improve our interpretation of monitoring dataset from such volcanoes.

Current models for magma transport in convergent margins suggest the prolonged storage and evolution of mantle-derived melts in the crust. This project will test whether a fast mode of magma transport even for large, long-lived arc magma systems exists and what conditions may facilitate such rapid ascent from the mantle to the surface. The time-integrative nature of geochemical data often precludes a direct comparison to geophysical signals that record transient processes. However, geochemical speedometers employing fast elemental diffusion in zoned magmatic crystals may bridge this observational gap and advance the application of geochemical tools to short time scale magmatic processes otherwise only investigated through geophysics. Such techniques have been successfully employed for near-surface magmatic processes; this projects aims at extending such approaches to the entire crustal magma ascent path.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Volcanoes are fed primarily from magmas generated in the mantle. This magma input is obscured within the Earth’s crust, where they stall, evolve, and mix. Especially in convergent margin settings where ocean crust subducts beneath continental crust magma transit is slowed and mantle signals are mostly lost. Those signals are essential for elemental cycling between the Earth surface and the Earth interior. Where magmas stall and for how long is not only important for the understanding of how mantle signals are obscured, but it provides important constraints on how magmas drive volcanic eruptions. What are the melt and crystal components that contribute to the eruptions? When did the final erupting magma get assembled and at which rates did it move to the surface? These questions can be partially addressed by studying crystals carried in the magma to the surface that record the history during crystal growth and further suspension in the melt. Their geochemical signatures and zoning patterns reveal subsurface processes to the scientists, just like spectators at a sports event witness the the on- and off-field events in the stadium. Each spectator has their own experience and memories, with some people being closer to some action and others missing some of it. Collectively they provide a detailed account of what happened and just like in an volcanic eruption that mixes up the crystals on ascent, spectators mix as they leave the stadium. An exit interviewer has to reconcile each individual account in space and time of the events to develop a full consistent narrative of what happened and why. Our spectators are primarily olivine crystals that grow early in the magma and therefore have a more complete history. At the same time, they lose information diffusively (just like a person with memory loss problems may have a limited memory in time).

We have studied olivines and melt inclusions hosted in them in various natural settings (Irazú volcano, Costa Rica; Cinder Cone, Cascades; Shiveluch, Kamchatka; Los Hornitos, Chile) and experimentally. At Irazú we addressed a key question: how to distinguish between new growth and diffusive equilibration within a crystal? We used isotope zoning signatures within the crystals to show that diffusion is largely responsible for the gradual variations seen in crystal compositions. Transient changes in melt composition are unlikely to be recorded by growth. Instead the crystal remembers the initial melt composition and the final composition after a mixing event. At Cinder Cone, we showed that primitive magmas can be complex mixtures of mantle melts that may even change over the course of the eruption. At Shiveluch and experimentally we have been exploring the role of water in magma generation and transport in magmas associated with the Ring of Fire. It is important to constrain how wet arc magmas are, as water is the major driver for explosive behavior and as it also drives melting in the mantle by lowering the mantle melting temperature. In experiments we showed that melt inclusions may not be effective recorders of water contents in primitive melts. Water-rich melts (> 9wt%) do not quench easily to glass and therefore are potentially biased/excluded from analyses. Shiveluch lavas with primitive olivine overgrown by magnesian hornblende are an example of a primitive magma that requires very water rich conditions. Lastly, at Los Hornitos we have been studying olivine phenocrysts that have compositions in equilibrium with mantle peridotite (>Fo90) and reach the surface despite a long transit through 45 km of continental crust. How olivines grow and therefore record magmatic processes has been questioned in other volcanoes (dendritic growth followed by filling in). Such growth habits have not been reported for arc volcanoes, where crustal storage is considered longer than in volcanoes like Hawaii. Los Hornitos olivines may represent the first example of the preservation of dendritic growth in an arc setting.

 

The project helped an early-career investigator to establish himself within the research community. At the University of Nevada, Reno a post-doctoral researcher and two graduate students were partially funded. Two undergraduate students participated in some of the research activities. New collaborations were developed between research groups at University of Nevada, Reno (UNR) and the Washington University in St. Louis. Moreover, this grant let the UNR research group to establish an ongoing research collaboration with colleagues from the Alaska Volcano Observatory (USGS) and the University of Alaska, Fairbanks.
